courseDescription: Explore the rich tapestry of biblical culture, ancient customs, and church history from the Old Testament through the early church period.

beginner.title: Foundations of Biblical Culture
beginner.description: Understanding the world of the Bible - daily life, customs, and cultural practices

lessons.title: Introduction to the Biblical World
topics: Geography of the Ancient Near East
Time periods: Patriarchal, Exodus, Judges, Kingdom, Exile, Post-Exile
The three major regions: Mesopotamia, Egypt, Canaan
Climate and agriculture in ancient Israel
keyPoints: The biblical world spanned from Egypt to Mesopotamia
Understanding geography helps interpret many biblical narratives
Agricultural cycles shaped religious festivals and daily life
Trade routes connected Israel to surrounding nations

lessons.title: Daily Life in Ancient Israel
keyPoints: Extended families lived together in compounds
Most Israelites were farmers, shepherds, or craftsmen
Meals were communal and had social significance
Clothing indicated social status and occupation

lessons.title: The Biblical Calendar & Feast Days
topics: Agricultural and religious significance of festivals
keyPoints: Biblical calendar followed lunar cycles
Three pilgrimage feasts: Passover, Pentecost, Tabernacles
Feasts commemorate both agricultural cycles and salvation history
Jesus fulfilled feast day symbolism through His ministry

lessons.title: Worship & the Tabernacle
topics: Design and symbolism of the Tabernacle
keyPoints: Tabernacle design reflected God's holiness and presence
Sacrifices pointed forward to Christ's ultimate sacrifice
Only priests could enter the Holy Place
The Most Holy Place contained the Ark of the Covenant

lessons.title: Marriage & Family in Biblical Times
topics: Role of parents and extended family
keyPoints: Marriages were often arranged by families
Wedding celebrations lasted seven days
Firstborn sons received double inheritance
Children learned trades from their parents

intermediate.title: Temple, Tradition & Early Church
intermediate.description: Deep dive into Second Temple Judaism, Jesus' cultural context, and the birth of the church

lessons.title: The Second Temple Period
topics: Religious groups: Pharisees, Sadducees, Essenes, Zealots
keyPoints: 400 years between Old and New Testaments
Greek and Roman influence on Jewish culture
Temple was center of Jewish religious life
Various groups interpreted Torah differently

lessons.title: Synagogue & Jewish Education
topics: Education system: Bet Sefer, Bet Talmud, Bet Midrash
keyPoints: Synagogues developed during Babylonian exile
Centers for prayer, study, and community
Jesus regularly taught in synagogues
Paul used synagogues as starting point for evangelism

lessons.title: Jesus in His Cultural Context
topics: Jesus as a rabbi and teacher
keyPoints: Jesus lived as a devout Jew observing Torah
His parables used familiar agricultural imagery
He challenged legalistic interpretations of the Law
Many expected a political/military Messiah

lessons.title: Biblical Festivals & Jesus
topics: Jesus and Passover - The Last Supper
Jesus at the Feast of Tabernacles
keyPoints: Jesus died during Passover as the Lamb of God
Holy Spirit came on Pentecost/Shavuot
Jesus proclaimed Himself living water at Tabernacles
Feasts form a prophetic calendar of redemption

lessons.title: Birth of the Church (Acts 1-12)
topics: Gospel spreads to Samaria and Gentiles
keyPoints: Church began with 120 believers, grew to thousands
Early believers shared possessions communally
Persecution scattered Christians, spreading the gospel
God revealed gospel was for all nations, not just Jews

lessons.title: Paul's Missionary Journeys
keyPoints: Paul targeted major urban centers
He began in synagogues, then reached Gentiles
Paul established leadership in each church
His letters addressed specific church issues

advanced.title: Early Church History & Development
advanced.description: From apostolic fathers through the early church councils and theological development

lessons.title: The Apostolic Fathers
keyPoints: These leaders knew the apostles personally
Their writings preserve apostolic teaching
They addressed heresies and maintained orthodoxy
Emphasized episcopal church structure

lessons.title: Persecution & Martyrdom
topics: Roman persecution under Nero, Domitian, Decius
Edict of Milan (313 AD) - Constantine's tolerance
keyPoints: Christians refused to worship Roman gods/emperor
Persecution was sporadic, not constant
Blood of martyrs became 'seed of the church'
Constantine ended persecution, favored Christianity

lessons.title: Early Heresies & Orthodoxy
keyPoints: Heresies forced church to clarify core beliefs
Canon of Scripture established to counter false teachings
Apostolic succession emphasized for authority
Creeds summarized orthodox Christian belief

lessons.title: The Ecumenical Councils
topics: Council of Nicaea (325) - deity of Christ
Council of Ephesus (431) - nature of Mary
Council of Chalcedon (451) - two natures of Christ
keyPoints: Councils resolved major theological disputes
Nicaea affirmed Jesus is fully God
Chalcedon affirmed Jesus is fully God and fully human
Creeds became standard of orthodoxy

lessons.title: The Church Fathers & Theology
keyPoints: Church fathers defended and explained the faith
They wrote commentaries, apologetics, theology
Different schools: Alexandrian vs. Antiochene
Their work shaped all later Christian theology

lessons.title: Monasticism & Early Worship
keyPoints: Monasticism arose from desire for spiritual devotion
Monks preserved Scripture and learning
Liturgical worship developed from synagogue patterns
Church calendar commemorated Christ's life and saints

lessons.title: Biblical Geography Deep Dive
keyPoints: Geography shaped biblical events and theology
Modern archaeology confirms many biblical locations
Travel in ancient world was difficult but common
Strategic locations became centers of Christianity
